lesson.title: Building Layouts: Part 1
lesson.summary: Learn how to place layouts on a page to create images, buttons, and text on a phone screen

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text:
# Introduction

Congratulations on taking the first step to learning Android! By the end of this course, you’ll know how to make a single-screen Android app with text and images. We’ll discuss how to create a user interface through a series of short videos with lots of hands-on practice.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text: In the practice set, we’ll walk through step-by-step how to create an app, like this birthday card, and show you how to run it on an Android device.

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.text: Then you’ll have a chance to customize the card for a loved one for any special occasion coming up. When you look at your phone, how many apps were created specifically for you in mind? Creating a mobile app is a highly creative process, where adding a personal touch can truly make an app shine. To see heartwarming and funny cards created by students, check out the discussion forum. In this course, you’ll learn how to use Android Studio, the tool that professional developers use to create apps. Be sure that your computer meets the system requirements for Android Studio. The course will take about 3 - 5 hours of dedicated work, but it can widely vary per student, so take your time to learn the concepts. One last note about prerequisites. If you have no prior programming experience, then this course is for you. We’ll assume that you already have basic computer skills and know how to use a smartphone. We’ll be your instructors guiding you through the course, and we can’t wait to see what you create!

atoms.title: Introduction
atoms.caption: Katherine Kuan, Kunal Chawla, and Lyla Fujiwara

atoms.title: Preparing for the Journey Ahead
atoms.text:
# Preparing for the Journey Ahead

## Common obstacles

When speaking with many students, we found common reasons why they were hesitant to start learning Android:

* Lack of confidence that they can be a developer
* Code seems intimidating
* Tools seem complex
* Too much jargon
* Concepts are too abstract

We take these obstacles seriously and came up with ways to try to help you overcome them. Our aim is to make the learning curve as comfortable as possible for you as a student, so your confidence grows with each new concept mastered. 

## Visuals

For all the visual learners out there, we use lots of drawings, analogies, and props to explain technical concepts that otherwise could be confusing.

atoms.title: Vocab Glossary
atoms.text: ## Vocab Glossary We also don’t want you to be overwhelmed by all the jargon that comes up, or to feel like you need to memorize it. As a result, we’ve created a custom vocabulary glossary to help you. If you ever forget what a word means, you can check out the glossary for a beautiful image, description, and code sample.

atoms.title: Preparing for the Journey Ahead
atoms.text:
## Instructor Notes

When navigating in the Udacity classroom, if you scroll vertically below a video, you’ll often find instructor notes. In these notes, we’ve provided supplementary links to other resources that you can read to get more information about the concepts covered in the video.

## Learning Something New

If you’re motivated and willing to be persistent, we are fully confident in your ability to learn Android development. We have thousands of students who have gone from no coding experience to building simple apps on their own. You can do this!
The first thing in Android you need to learn is something called **Views**.

atoms.title: Views
atoms.instructor_notes: Camel case is a convention that is not limited to programming. If you've ever used FedEx, listened to an iPod, created a PowerPoint, or eaten at McDonalds, you've encountered camel case! We used a lot of new words in this video! - Layout - User Interface - TextView - ImageView - Button - Camel case Don't worry, you don't have to memorize them. You can look up their definitions by clicking here and searching for them. Believe it or not, professional developers don't memorize everything -- looking up information is a key part of the job! You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

complex_prompt.text: Match each view below with its corresponding view type.

concepts.title: Quiz: Picking Views for YouTube App

atoms.title: TODO Picking Views For YouTube App

atoms.text: # Quiz: Picking Views for Youtube App
**NOTE**: In the screenshot above, the YouTube icon is static and simply meant to reflect the App's branding. There is no interactivity intended for it.

complex_prompt.text: Match each view below with its corresponding ViewType.

atoms.title: Talking To Your Phone
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - Code - XML - Integrated development environment (IDE) - This is the tool in which we will write our code. Similar to how we can use GMail as the tool to write an email, to write code for Android, we will use an IDE an IDE called Android Studio. You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

answer.text:
- Weird angle brackets
- Don't know what "android:text" means
- Says "Happy Birthday", which appears on phone
- Has height and width

atoms.title: XML Syntax
atoms.instructor_notes: Here are the words we introduced in this video: - XML element - Tag - Self-closing tags - Attributes - Syntax You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary. Believe it or not, professional developers don't memorize everything -- looking up information is a key part of the job! Correction: We incorrectly listed one of the attributes to be android:layout_weight. The correct attribute is android:layout_width.

atoms.title: Change the TextView
atoms.instructor_notes: Words we used in this video: - Android Studio - Device - Density-Independent Pixels You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary. Link to the XML Visualizer In case you're wondering, 48dp translates to approximately 9mm in physical size. See more info here **What does Density-Independent Pixel actually mean?** You might be familiar with a pixel, which is a small illuminated area on a screen. Screens are essentially made up of hundreds of thousands of these pixels. **So what is a "density independent" pixel?** Well, better screens will often have more pixels in the same amount of space. The number of pixels in a fixed space is known as the screen's pixel density. In case you're wondering, 48dp translates to approximately 9mm in physical size. See more info here

atoms.title: Change the TextView
tasks: Change the text in the TextView
Try changing the size of the TextView
Try to create an error. Then undo it.
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.

atoms.title: Getting Past Errors
atoms.instructor_notes: *Note that Android uses the American-English spelling of the word "gray".* Debugging steps: 1. Read the error message 2. Compare to working code 3. Undo 4. Ask for help Link to the XML Visualizer Link to the Common Views Cheatsheet Link to code sample How to take a screenshot

question.text: Describe at least 2 problems you see.

answer.text:
- TextView should not have an open space
- There should be a closing tag for TextView
- 150dp instead of 150
- "gray" instead of "groy"

atoms.title: Setting Wrap Content
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to the XML Visualizer Words we used in this video: - Hard coding - wrap_content You can look up their definitions in the Vocab Glossary.

atoms.title: wrap_content
tasks: Change the width and height of the TextView to wrap_content
Change the text to be more than 1 line of text on the device
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.

atoms.title: TextView Text Size
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to the XML Visualizer Material Design typography guidelines The new term we used in this video: - Scale-Independent Pixels You can look up the definition in the Vocab Glossary.

atoms.title: Text Size
tasks: Change the TextView font size using sizes from Material Design spec
Try learning about text appearance from Google+ #AndroidDev #Protip
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.

atoms.title: TextView Text Color
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to the XML Visualizer Material Design color palette More info on Hex colors Click here and search for: - Hex color

atoms.title: Text Color
tasks: Change the color of the background and text to 2 different colors from the Material Design Spec
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.

atoms.title: Simple ImageView
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to the XML Visualizer *Note:* The "Available Images" link is in the bottom left corner of the XML Visualizer!

atoms.title: ImageView
tasks: Change the height and width to be a fixed dp value (i.e. 100dp)
Change scaleType between center and centerCrop
Change to a different image (see Available Images link)
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.

atoms.title: Documentation
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to the XML visualizer New term we used in this video: - Documentation You can look up the definition in the Vocab Glossary. If you're wondering which link to click, look for the first one that starts with **developer.android.com**. Any website that starts with that web address is part of the official Android developer website and documentation.

atoms.title: Looking at Documentation
tasks: Use Find feature (Ctl + F or Cmd + F) in web browser to search the page for the XML attribute that makes TextView text bold or italic
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! Check out the solution video below.
